title: Complete React Development Course
description: Master React from basics to advanced concepts. Learn hooks, context, routing, and state management with real-world projects.

options: A JavaScript library for building user interfaces
questions.explanation: React is a JavaScript library developed by Facebook for building user interfaces, especially web applications.
React components are reusable pieces of UI that can be combined to create complex applications.

transcript.text: Welcome to our introduction to React! In this lesson, we'll explore what React is and why it's become so popular in modern web development.
React is a JavaScript library developed by Facebook for building user interfaces. It's particularly good at creating interactive and dynamic web applications.
One of React's key features is its component-based architecture, which allows developers to build encapsulated components that manage their own state.

questions.explanation: JSX is a syntax extension for JavaScript that allows you to write HTML-like code in JavaScript files.

transcript.text: Now let's dive into JSX, which is a syntax extension for JavaScript that allows you to write HTML-like code in your JavaScript files.
JSX makes it easy to describe what the UI should look like. It's similar to HTML, but with some important differences we'll explore.
Components are the building blocks of React applications. They're reusable pieces of code that return JSX to describe what should appear on the screen.

questions.text: What is the difference between state and props?
options: State is mutable, props are immutable
Props are mutable, state is immutable
questions.explanation: State is mutable and managed within a component, while props are immutable and passed from parent components.

transcript.text: Understanding state and props is crucial for React development. Let's start with props, which are how components receive data from their parent components.
Props are read-only and help you pass data down your component tree. State, on the other hand, is mutable and managed within a component.
The useState hook is how we add state to functional components. It returns an array with the current state value and a function to update it.

title: Python Data Science Fundamentals
description: Learn Python for data science with pandas, numpy, and matplotlib. Perfect for beginners starting their data science journey.

questions.text: Which library is commonly used for data manipulation in Python?
questions.explanation: Pandas is the most commonly used library for data manipulation and analysis in Python.

transcript.text: Welcome to Python for data science! We'll start with the fundamental concepts and libraries that make Python so powerful for data analysis.
Pandas is the cornerstone library for data manipulation in Python. It provides data structures like DataFrames that make working with structured data intuitive.
NumPy provides the numerical computing foundation, while Matplotlib helps us create visualizations to understand our data better.

questions.text: What is a DataFrame in pandas?
questions.explanation: A DataFrame is a 2-dimensional data structure in pandas, similar to a table or spreadsheet.

transcript.text: Let's explore pandas DataFrames in detail. A DataFrame is a 2-dimensional data structure that can store data of different types in columns.
You can think of a DataFrame like a spreadsheet or SQL table. It has rows and columns, and each column can contain different data types.
We'll learn how to create DataFrames, manipulate data, filter rows, select columns, and perform basic statistical operations.

title: Mobile App Development with React Native
description: Build cross-platform mobile apps using React Native. Learn navigation, state management, and native module integration.

questions.explanation: React Native is a framework for building mobile applications using React and JavaScript.

transcript.text: Welcome to React Native! This framework allows you to build mobile apps using React and JavaScript that run on both iOS and Android.
Unlike web development, React Native uses native components instead of web components. This means better performance and a more native feel.
We'll explore the core components like View, Text, and ScrollView, and learn how they differ from their web counterparts.

questions.text: Which library is commonly used for navigation in React Native?
questions.explanation: React Navigation is the most popular navigation library for React Native applications.

transcript.text: Navigation is crucial in mobile apps. React Navigation is the standard library for handling navigation between screens in React Native applications.
We'll explore different navigation patterns like Stack Navigation for hierarchical navigation and Tab Navigation for switching between main sections.
You'll learn how to pass parameters between screens, handle deep linking, and create smooth navigation experiences that feel native to each platform.

title: UI/UX Design Principles
description: Learn fundamental design principles, user research methods, and prototyping techniques for creating exceptional user experiences.

questions.text: What is the main goal of UX design?
questions.explanation: The main goal of UX design is to improve user satisfaction by making products more usable and accessible.

transcript.text: Design fundamentals are the building blocks of great user experiences. Let's start with the basic principles that guide effective design.
The main goal of UX design is to create products that are not just functional, but delightful to use. This means focusing on user needs and behaviors.
We'll explore principles like hierarchy, contrast, alignment, and proximity - the foundations that make interfaces intuitive and accessible.

options: A fictional character representing a user segment
questions.explanation: A user persona is a fictional character created to represent a specific user segment, helping designers understand user needs and behaviors.

transcript.text: User research is the foundation of good design. Before we design anything, we need to understand who our users are and what they need.
User personas are fictional characters that represent segments of your user base. They help us make design decisions based on real user needs.
We'll learn various research methods like interviews, surveys, and usability testing to gather insights that inform our design decisions.

title: Advanced JavaScript Concepts
description: Deep dive into advanced JavaScript topics including closures, prototypes, async programming, and modern ES6+ features.

questions.text: What is a closure in JavaScript?
options: A function that returns another function
A function that has access to variables from its outer scope
A way to close a program
questions.explanation: A closure is a function that has access to variables from its outer (enclosing) scope even after the outer function has returned.

transcript.text: Closures are one of JavaScript's most powerful features. A closure gives you access to an outer function's scope from an inner function.
This means that even after the outer function has finished executing, the inner function still has access to the outer function's variables.
Closures are commonly used for data privacy, creating function factories, and in callback functions. Let's explore these patterns in detail.

questions.text: What is the difference between async/await and Promises?
options: Async/await is syntactic sugar for Promises
questions.explanation: Async/await is syntactic sugar that makes working with Promises easier and more readable, but it's built on top of Promises.

transcript.text: Asynchronous programming is essential in modern JavaScript. Let's explore how async/await makes working with asynchronous code more readable.
Async/await is built on top of Promises, providing a cleaner syntax for handling asynchronous operations without callback hell.
We'll learn how to handle errors with try/catch blocks, work with multiple async operations, and understand the execution order of async code.

title: Machine Learning with Python
description: Introduction to machine learning concepts using Python. Learn supervised and unsupervised learning with scikit-learn.

questions.explanation: Supervised learning is a type of machine learning where the algorithm learns from labeled training data to make predictions on new, unseen data.

transcript.text: Machine learning is about teaching computers to learn patterns from data. Let's start with supervised learning, where we have labeled training data.
In supervised learning, the algorithm learns from examples with known correct answers, then uses that knowledge to make predictions on new data.
We'll explore different types of supervised learning including classification for predicting categories and regression for predicting numerical values.
